awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum science and technology promises realization of powerful quantum computational resource, a
quantum cloud. While the exact implementation of quantum processing nodes and qubits to be used in
such networks are still the topic of research and debate, the information between the nodes will surely be
carried by photons. Therefore, interfacing different types of qubits with photons at telecommunication wavelengths is critical for realization of scalable distributed quantum computational systems. This can lead to realization of high-speed electro-optic modulators and microwave photonics
systems that will find applications in classical and quantum optical networks, as well as the study of
interesting and emerging physical phenomena including gauge field for photons, topological photonics,
strongly-coupled quantum systems and so on.  This program is focused on superconducting quantum technology, a leading quantum computing platform, that faces a challenge: efficient transfer of quantum information encoded into microwave photons over large distances.
The program will provide a unique training ground for involved students and help train a
new generation of quantum engineers and scientists.

Technical: The goal of the proposed program is to achieve low-noise microwave-to-optical photon conversion with unity efficiency, and then leverage this to demonstrate quantum state transfer between superconducting qubit and a telecom photon. Superconducting qubit will be used as an on-demand source of microwave photons, by leveraging quantum interference effects. The qubit will be strongly coupled to a microwave resonator realized in few-atomic-layer superconducting films that exhibit unique microwave-plasmonic properties. These include low dissipation, high nonlinearity, and exceptionally high kinetic inductance, resulting in extraordinarily slow signal propagation. This will enable realization of compact microwave resonators that allow for strong coupling to a qubit on one end, and that match the dimensions of the optical circuits on the other end. Microwave-to-optical photon conversion will be based on the electrooptics approach using ultra low loss integrated lithium-niobate platform. The process will be enhanced by using triply resonant geometry that combines two optical and one microwave resonator.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Quantum science and technology promises realization of powerful quantum computational resource – a quantum cloud. Among many platforms that are being explored to realize quantum computers, superconductors are the most developed at the moment. In this approach, quantum bits – qubits – are realized in superconducting material, while interaction between them is mitigated using photons at microwave frequencies. While suitable for on-chip interactions, microwave photons – owing to their small energy - are not suitable to carry quantum information over distances exceeding ten meters even. Classical medium (e.g. building based) and large scale networks typically rely on photons at optical frequencies as information carriers, and it is expected that the same will be true in the case of quantum networks: optical photons will be used to connect multiple quantum computers thus realizing powerful distributed computational resources. Therefore, it is important to develop transducers that can convert quantum information between optical and microwave photons with high fidelity. The focus of this program was development of such quantum transducers.

Intellectual merits: The main goal of the program was to achieve low-noise microwave-to-optical photon conversion with unity efficiency. Our approach took advantage of large electro-optic effect in thin film lithium niobate (TFLN) photonics platform, enhanced by ultra-low loss optical resonators that we have developed. Electro-optic effect results in change of refractive index of TFLN material when electrical signals (at microwave frequency in our case) are applied, which in turn results in change of the color of optical photon propagating within the TFLN device, thus providing the required information transduction. The process is enhanced by using triply resonant geometry that combines two optical and one microwave resonator. First, we developed theoretical framework required to study the process of frequency conversion across large frequency range, and then used it to design efficient transducers. Our theoretical studies showed that quantum transduction with unity efficiency is possible in realistic system. Next, we have developed fabrication recipes to realize quantum transducers that combine TFLN with high performance superconductors. Importantly, our approach maintains high performance of both optical and microwave materials and devices. Using this approach, we have demonstrated the ability to transduce microwave photons with low noise. Further improvements in design and fabrication of the devices are expected to increase the conversion efficiency to unity, as theoretically predicted.

Broader impact: Photons at microwave and optical frequencies enable much of modern technology, including fiber-optic communications, radar technology, wireless communications, and more recently quantum computation and communication. Thus, the ability to efficiently convert information between photons having orders-of-magnitude different energies is important. Our program enabled breakthroughs in microwave and optical materials, development of novel device concepts, and realization of scalable quantum networks. This lead to realization of high-speed electro-optic modulators and microwave photonics systems that have applications in classical and quantum optical networks. Our interdisciplinary science and engineering program was grounded in material science, nanofabrication, microwave, photonics, superconducting physics, and quantum computing and communication. In our program, three key advances from disparate fields converged to realize  our goals: a novel engineering scheme for coupling optical systems to microwave single photons, a novel material designed to slow signal propagation and enhance microwave electric field for interaction between microwave and optical photons, and a novel qubit readout system based on interaction with optical photons. The program provided a unique training ground for involved students and help train a new generation of quantum engineers and scientists. Total of seven graduate students, three postdocs, and several undergrad research interns were trained within the scope of the program. Progress demonstrated within the program resulted in interest from and collaboration with several industrial partners.
